The sustainable transformation of biomass-derived platform molecules into value-added chemicals is pivotal for reducing environmental hazards and fossil resource dependence. Herein, we report a silicon-mediated interface engineering strategy to tailor the Lewis acidity of HfOx catalysts, enabling green catalytic transfer hydrogenation (CTH) of toxic furfural (FAL) to safer furfuryl alcohol (FOL). By integrating ZSM-5 molecular sieves with HfOx through a hydrothermal route, in situ dissolved silicon species were found to dynamically regulate HfOx framework condensation. This process generated hierarchical porosity with accessible acidic sites and formed Si-O-Hf interfacial bonds that induced electron-deficient Hf centers. The optimized HfOx@ZSM-5-(260) catalyst achieved >99 % FAL conversion and FOL selectivity within 1 h at 160°C, effectively suppressing hazardous resinification byproducts. Notably, the catalyst, synthesized from low-toxicity Hf and Si precursors, retained >95 % FOL selectivity over three consecutive cycles, demonstrating robust stability in waste-minimized processes. Mechanistic studies revealed a linear correlation between silicon doping levels and Lewis acid strength, establishing a universal descriptor for eco-friendly catalyst design in hydrogen transfer reactions. This work underscores the potential of interfacial electronic modulation in mitigating toxic byproducts during biomass valorization, offering a sustainable pathway aligned with green chemistry principles. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Furfural Furfuryl alcohol Hafnium oxide Si doping Catalytic transfer hydrogenation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The imperative to decarbonize the chemical industry and mitigate ecological risks associated with petrochemicals has driven significant interest in the sustainable valorization of biomass-derived platform molecules into value-added chemicals [1–4]. Among these molecules, furfural (FAL), a key lignocellulosic platform compound, presents a dual opportunity and challenge. Its unsaturated aldehyde group and furan ring offer versatile modification sites, with the selective hydrogenation of the aldehyde group to furfuryl alcohol (FOL) beign partivularly crucial. This transformation enhances biomass utilization efficiency and reduces the ecotoxicological burden compared to conventional routes [5]. Conventional FAL hydrogenation to FOL often relies on high-pressure H2 and energy-intensive conditions (>200°C), employing hazardous metal catalysts (e.g., Pt/CuCr2O4) that pose risks of secondary pollution [6–8]. Catalytic transfer hydrogenation (CTH), utilizing a liquid hydrogen donor like isopropanol, offers a promising greener alternative, circumventing the need for high-pressure H₂ and potentially hazardous catalysts. However, achieving near-quantitative FOL yields under truly mild conditions remains elusive. This necessitates the development of novel catalysts that reconcile high atomic efficiency with environmental benignity [9]. The Meerwein-Ponndorf-Verley (MPV) mechanism underpins this CTH transformation. In this pathway, FAL and isopropanol (acting as both hydrogen donor and solvent) adsorb onto the catalyst surface, forming a transient six-membered ring transition state. This facilitates the precise transfer of a hydride (β-hydrogen) from isopropanol to the carbonyl carbon of FAL, resulting in FOL formation and the stoichiometric oxidation of isopropanol to acetone [10–12]. Crucially, the catalyst remains unconsumed and is regenerated for subsequent cycles. The MPV mechanism highlights the pivotal role of the catalyst, whose physicochemical properties critically govern both product selectivity and yield. Consequently, significant research has focused on designing catalysts featuring Zr or Hf as strong Lewis acidic active centers, leveraging the electron deficiency of their outer shells [13,14]. To address practical limitations like catalyst recovery and enhance active site accessibility, these metals are typically immobilized on supports or incorporated into Metal-Organic Framework (MOF) hybrid materials, where the support/MOF structure provides high surface area and facilitates reactant access [15,16]. In contrast, the direct use of bulk metal oxides (e.g., ZrO2) as catalysts for this reaction is less explored, primarily due to their typically lower intrinsic activity compared to supported or MOF-based systems. Studies indicate that this lower activity stems from common synthesis conditions: high-temperature calcination (>500°C) promotes excessive metal-oxygen coordination and dense crystallization [10,14]. This leads to two critical drawbacks: (i) Severely limited exposure of active Lewis acid sites: Necessitating high catalyst loadings and extended reaction times, which increase energy consumption and promote unwanted byproduct formation. (ii) Electron saturation at metal centers: Attenuating the essential Lewis acidity and inadvertently favoring hazardous side reactions, such as uncontrolled polymerization leading to humins formation [17,18]. Despite these challenges, bulk metal oxides possess inherent advantages as solid catalysts: they can function directly as active components (eliminating the need and cost for additional support synthesis) and serve as high-activity supports themselves for synergistic catalysis with other elements [19–21]. Therefore, overcoming the inherent low activity limitation of bulk metal oxide catalysts represents a significant and compelling research gap. Addressing this gap holds the key to unlocking their full potential for efficient and sustainable biomass conversion via MPV reactions. Building upon our recent discovery that hydrothermally synthesized HfO2 with abundant surface hydroxyls exhibits superior CTH activity compared to calcined analogues—owing to enhanced Lewis acidity and accessible active sites [22]—we propose a targeted silicon-doping strategy to synergistically engineer the nanostructure and electronic landscape of HfOx. This is achieved by integrating ZSM-5 molecular sieves with tunable Si/Al ratios into the hydrothermal synthesis, enabling in situ silicon dissolution that fundamentally redirects HfOx polycondensation pathways. Crucially, the infiltrated silicon species perform a dual function distinct from conventional carrier effects [23–25]: (i) Structural modulation—partial inhibition of HfOx cluster condensation generates hierarchical porosity, exposing occluded acidic sites while maintaining mechanical stability; (ii) Electronic tailoring—formation of interfacial Si-O-Hf bonds induces electron withdrawal from Hf centers, creating electron-deficient species with intensified Lewis acidity. This bifunctional engineering—concurrently optimizing active site accessibility and electronic density—endows the Si-doped HfOx with exceptional catalytic performance, achieving >80 % conversion within 10 min at 160°C while maintaining >95 % product selectivity. Through mechanistic correlation of silicon doping levels with Lewis acid strength, we establish a universal design principle for eco-friendly catalysts that operate efficiently under mild conditions, suppress toxic byproducts, and align intrinsically with the 12 principles of green chemistry. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation 2.1.1 HfOx@ZSM-5-(x) The HfOx@ZSM-5-(x) was synthesized by the hydrothermal method (where x represents the initial Si/Al ratio of ZSM-5) and all catalysts were synthesized in a similar method. For example, 0.4486 g of HfCl4 and 1 g of ZSM-5-(260) were added to a 2 mol/L NaOH solution (20 mL) and stirred to a uniform suspension liquid at room temperature. The solution was then transferred to a 25 mL hydrothermal kettle and reacted at 120°C for 24 h. The white precipitate was separated by suction filtration and washed with deionized water and ethanol for neutralization. Finally, the obtained sample was gently ground to powder after drying at 50°C for 12 h, which named as HfOx@ZSM-5-(260). 2.1.2 HfO2 0.4486 g HfCl4 was added to a 2 mol/L NaOH solution (20 mL) and stirred for 1 h at room temperature. The resulting colloidal suspension was transferred to a 25 mL hydrothermal kettle and reacted at 120°C for 24 h. Centrifuging the white precipitate with deionized water and ethanol to neutrality. Finally, the sample was dried at 50°C for 12 h and ground to a powder. 2.1.3 ZSM-5-(x)-AH The ZSM-5-(x)-AH catalysts were prepared using consistent methods (where x representing the initial Si/Al ratio of ZSM-5). Taking ZSM-5-(260)-AH as an example, 1 g of ZSM-5-(260) was added to a 2 mol/L NaOH solution (20 mL) and stirred at room temperature for 1 h. The solution was transferred to a 25 mL hydrothermal kettle and hydrothermal treatment at 120°C for 24 h. The obtained yellow precipitate was centrifuged to neutralization using deionized water and ethanol. Finally, the product was dried at 50°C for 12 h and ground to a powder. 2.1.4 HfO2/ZSM-5-(x)-AH HfO2/ZSM-5-(x)-AH was obtained by grinding with The HfO2 and ZSM-5-(x)-AH. 2.2 Catalytic activity tests A 50 mL cylindrical stainless-steel reactor equipped with a thermocouple-controlled temperature and magnetic stirrer was used to explore the catalytic activity. Typically, 0.30 g FAL, 0.10 g catalyst, and 20 mL isopropanol were putted into the reactor, followed by sealing for subsequent reaction under controlled temperature with stirring at 360 rpm. After completion of the reaction, the reactor was immediately placed into a cold-water bath for rapid cooling. Then, the catalyst and reaction liquid were separated by filtration, and the catalyst can be used for recycling experiments while the reaction liquid was subjected to product analysis. The liquid products were identified using a gas chromatography-mass spectrometer (GC-MS, Thermofisher Trace 1300 and ISQ LT) fitted with a HP-5 MS column (15 m × 250 μm × 0.25 μm). The quantitative analysis of liquid products was conducted on an Agilent GC-7820 series with a flame ionization detector (FID) and DB-FFAP column (30 m × 320 μm × 0.25 μm). The conversion of FAL, yield and selectivity of FOL were calculated using the internal standard method. The calculation formulae are presented as follows: (1) C FAL ( mol % ) = ( 1 − final mol of FAL initial mol of FAL ) × 100 % (2) Y FOL ( mol % ) = mol of FOL initial mol of FAL × 100 % (3) S FOL ( mol % ) = yield of FOL conversion of FAL × 100 % 2.3 Adsorption experiments and recycling tests In a typical adsorption experiment, a certain amount of catalyst was stirred with FAL and isopropyl alcohol at room temperature for 12 h. Then the catalyst was separated from the reaction solution. The liquid phase products were identified by GC and calculated by the following equations: (4) Qe ( mg g ) = initial weight of FAL − final weight of FAL weight of catalyst (5) Qe ( mg g ) = initial weight of FOL − final weight of FOL weight of catalyst In recycling tests, the catalyst is separated from the reaction solution and washed with deionized water and ethanol many times before drying. The catalyst is then directly used in the next cycle. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst screening Initially, the experimental parameters of HfOx@ZSM-5-(260) were systematically investigated, and its activity was evaluated by the CTH reaction of FAL to FOL. The experimental findings demonstrated that both higher and lower concentrations of NaOH adversely affect the catalytic performance, and the best results achieved under a concentration of 2 mol/L NaOH (Fig. S1A). In addition, the catalyst performed best when the theoretical Hf loading increased to 20 wt%, and higher Hf content will not produce a significant change in catalytic activity (Fig. S1B). On this basis, we investigated the impact of the Si/Al ratio of ZSM-5. The blank experiment indicated that the reaction cannot be carried out without a catalyst (Table 1 , entry 1). In addition, even though ZSM-5 contains a small amount of Al that can serve as Lewis acid sites, it itself cannot catalyze FAL alone, implying a core role of Hf species in this transformation (Table 1, entry 2-3) [26–28]. Through adjusting the reaction time and temperature to amplify the reaction changing, we found the catalytic performance was enhanced by the higher Si/Al ratio, which HfOx@ZSM-5-(260) with highest ratio got over 99 % of FAL conversion and FOL yield under 160°C and 1 h (Table 1, entry 4-13). This effect surpasses numerous catalysts that have been reported for the hydrogenation of FAL to FOL [13,29,30]. The cyclic stability of HfOx@ZSM-5-(260) was also tested, the catalyst revealed a partial decrease in activity over reaction times, but it still maintains more than 85 % of FAL conversion and FOL yield, indicating the catalyst has a good cycle stability (Table 1, entry 14-15). 3.2 Structural analysis of the catalyst To investigate the underlying reasons for the impact of the Si/Al ratio, we characterized different Si/Al ratio catalysts systematically. XRD was conducted to analyze the catalyst phase. As shown in Fig. 1A , ZSM-5 exhibits characteristic peaks at 23.1°, 23.9°, and 24.3° as its standard spectrum [29,30]. Following alkaline treatment, ZSM-5-AH displays many new and sharper crystallization peaks (Fig. 1B), and the overall curve of HfOx@ZSM-5 tends to be flat and without any prominent crystallization peak from HfO2 (Fig. 1C). BET results indicates that ZSM-5 has a surface area exceeding 200 m2·g−1, and this feature decreases significantly in ZSM-5-AH (4.4 m2·g−1) (Table 2 ), but HfOx@ZSM-5 (150 m2·g−1) confirmed the addition of Hf in the catalyst synthesis process mitigates the decrease in specific surface area. Further, there was almost no pore volume in ZSM-5-AH, but the incorporation of HfOx into ZSM-5 results in larger pore size and increased pore volume (more than 0.2 cm3·g−1, 12.8 nm) (Table 2, Fig. 1D-E). This conclusion is further supported by Fig. 1F-G, where the hysteresis loop transformed from type Ⅲ to type Ⅳ [31]. In order to directly observe the phase changes of the catalysts, SEM and TEM were employed for catalyst characterization. The untreated ZSM-5-(260) exhibits a smooth surface with regular columnar structure characteristics (Fig. 2A ). However, ZSM-5-(260)-AH completely collapsed to a spherical form (Fig. 2B), and in HfOx@ZSM-5-(260), the catalyst appears fluffy and amorphous without clear crystallization (Fig. 2C). These changes correspond with XRD and BET results, which all proved that AH treatment induced a significant collapse and crystallization of ZSM-5 because Si in ZSM-5 was hydrothermally dissolved, and the addition of Hf gave the catalyst a new morphology [32,33]. Furthermore, we prepared hydrothermal HfO2 for comparison, it has a smoother surface and a compact structure with numerous tiny pores upon magnification, which is completely different from the HfOx@ZSM-5-(260) (Fig. 2E). Element tracking reveals a high coincidence between the distributions of Hf and Si elements (Fig. 2F-G). The elemental composition of catalysts was further investigated using ICP-OES, as shown in Tables 3 and S1. A higher Si/Al ratio corresponds to a greater Si content in ZSM-5, and the Si content in ZSM-5-AH significantly decreases from 27.6 % to 6.1 % after AH treatment. Besides, the ICP test results reveal that the actual Hf loading does not matching the theoretical value due to inevitable uneven distribution of oxide during formation, resulting in partial deviation from the expected data. Fig. 3 depicts images of ZSM-5 after removing the supernatant after AH treatment, clearly demonstrating that higher Si/Al ratio will reduce residual solid material and increase Si concentration in the separated supernatant. The thermal stability of the catalyst was also investigated (Fig. S2). The experimental results indicating that the Si/Al ratio does not affect the heat loss. FTIR results display in Fig. 4A , ZSM-5-(260) has two vibration peaks belonging to SiO2 skeleton structure at 448 and 550 cm−1, respectively [34]. In ZSM-5-(260)-AH, the peak at 550 cm−1 disappears, while in HfOx@ZSM-5-(260), the original characteristic peak of ZSM-5 at 448 cm−1 further vanishes due to Hf coverage [35]. In addition, the Si-O bond characteristic peak at 1096 cm−1 in ZSM-5 shifts to 1033 cm−1 in both catalysts, indicating a reduction in the Si/Al ratio of the catalyst [36]. No Hf-O bond is detected in HfOx@ZSM-5-(260), which can be attributed to the low concentration of HfOx or Si doping altered the chemical environment surrounding the Hf-O bond. The changes observed in ZSM-5-(26) and ZSM-5-(43) are both consistent with those observed in ZSM-5-(260) (Fig. S3A-B). To further investigate the catalyst structure, hydrothermal HfO2 and HfO2/ZSM-5-(260)-AH were prepared and compared with HfOx@ZSM-5-(260) in terms of catalytic performance and structure. The experimental results reveal that under identical conditions, both HfO2 and HfO2/ZSM-5-(260)-AH exhibit same catalytic activity to that of HfOx@ZSM-5-(260) (Table 4 ). The H2-TPR technique was used to characterize the metal-support interaction in catalysts. Both HfO2/ZSM-5-(260)-AH and HfO2 exhibit similar test results, with varying hydrogen consumption temperatures. However, only HfOx@ZSM-5-(260) displays a broad absorption peak for hydrogen at approximately 350°C (Fig. 4B) [37]. The above three catalysts were further characterized using FTIR analysis (Fig. 4C). Among them, both HfO2 and HfO2/ZSM-5-(260)-AH exhibit an absorption peak at 750 cm−1 corresponding to the Hf-O bond, whereas the spectrum of HfOx@ZSM-5-(260) remains flat at this point.37 Additionally, only one Si-O bond absorption peak is observed at 987 cm−1, which shows a blue-shifted from 1075 cm−1 [38]. The above experimental results strongly demonstrate that the structure of HfOx@ZSM-5 is not merely a physical mixture of HfO2 and ZSM-5, and the remarkable catalytic performance of HfOx, as the primary active component, cannot be dissociated from the presence of Si during the formation process. Since the catalytic activity of Si is negligible, the outcome of the reaction is ultimately determined by the Lewis acid of Hf [39]. Therefore, we further investigated the acidity sites of the catalysts, with a particular focus on the modification of Si to Hf. Py-FTIR was employed to qualitatively and semi-quantitatively determine the acid sites of these catalysts. The adsorption of pyridine predominantly occurs at 1440 and 1590 cm−1, indicating that the surface acidic sites primarily exist as Lewis acid (Fig. 5A ) [40,41]. Moreover, it can be seen from the data trend that an increase in Si/Al ratio leads to a higher concentration of acidic sites on the surface of HfOx@ZSM-5 (Table 5 ). This finding is consistent with NH3-TPD results. Fig. 5B illustrates that all catalysts exhibit a single broad peak during NH3 desorption analysis, HfOx@ZSM-5-(260) with the highest Si/Al ratio displays the maximum NH3 consumption. This positive correlation between acidic site number and Si/Al ratio is associated with the specific surface area of the catalyst. A higher Si/Al ratio results in a larger specific surface area for catalysts, thereby exposing more highly active metal sites (Fig. 5C). XPS has further investigated the electron distribution of Si and Hf. The experimental results in Fig. S4 demonstrate that the valence state of Si in HfOx@ZSM-5-(260) has shifted from 4+ to 2+, confirming the dissolution of SiO2 (SiO2+2NaOH=Na2SiO3+H2O), and indicating that the remaining Si element in the catalyst no longer exists as SiO2, but rather exhibits a modified chemical environment [42]. The chemical environments of Hf and Si elements were also investigated in catalysts with varying Si/Al ratios (Fig. 6A ). The binding energy of Hf in HfOx@ZSM-5 exhibits a significant increase compared with pure oxide (18.0 and l6.3 eV) (Fig. S5), thereby providing an initial evidence that the incorporation of ZSM-5 enhancing the Lewis acidity [43–45]. Moreover, an increase in the Si/Al ratio of the catalyst results in a strengthening of binding energy of Hf 4f (from 18.2 and 16.4 eV to 18.7 and 16.9 eV), while simultaneously, there is a gradual weakening of the binding energy of Si 2p (from 102.1 eV to 101.6 eV) (Fig. 6B-C). This systematic variation suggests there was electron exchange between Hf and Si, which Si will withdraw electrons from around Hf, and this effect will become more pronounced at higher levels of Si content, also leading a stronger enhancement to Lewis acidity of Hf [20,46]. According to the experimental results and the hydrothermal preparation reaction mechanism of HfO2 (condensation reaction), it can be concluded that Si from ZSM-5 has been doped into the HfOx [47]. On the one hand, this doping hindered the complete condensation of Hf+ into dense oxides, resulting in a catalyst with a more porous structure and larger surface area, thereby exposing more acidic sites. On the other hand, due to the involvement of Si in electron sharing around Hf, the catalysts exhibit stronger Lewis acidity. These modifications undoubtedly contribute positively to promoting catalytic performance. The ICP results further confirm that higher Si/Al ratios correspond to increased Si content in HfOx@ZSM-5. Therefore, a higher Si/Al ratio leads to enhanced catalytic performance. In this work, ZSM-5 exhibits a unique role distinct from conventional supported catalyst carrier. Rather than simply embedding HfO2 onto its original porous structure with high specific surface area, the ZSM-5 structure is disrupted and the dissolved Si modified the HfOx species, thus resulting in remarkable catalytic effects for HfOx@ZSM-5. Moreover, the doping of Si can be precisely controlled by adjusting the Si/Al ratio (Fig. 7 ). This function of ZSM-5 has not been previously reported in literature. 3.3 Promoting effect of Si doping on FAL hydrogenation to FOL To further clarify the modification effect of Si, we compared pure HfO2 with synthetic samples and explored the reaction mechanism from adsorption, proton transfer, and desorption processes. Fig. 8A presents the FAL adsorption test on pure HfO2 and HfOx@ZSM-5-(260). Under the same system with isopropanol as the solvent system, there was no significant difference in the initial stage adsorption capacity of FAL between the two catalysts, but with the time extension, HfO2 exhibits stronger adsorption performance towards FAL. Employing these two catalysts in the hydrogenation reaction and evaluate conversion rate and yield at different time points. Although HfO2 achieved partial transformation of FAL, the yield was just got consistently 20 % and only can only be improved by prolonging the reaction time (Fig. 8B). In HfOx@ZSM-5-(260), to our surprise, the catalyst exhibits a very strong catalytic ability with nearly 80 % of FAL conversion and FOL yield with 10 min, and this higher FOL selectivity indicating that the transformation of FAL to FOL started immediately upon FAL being adsorbed from the reaction liquid to the catalyst (Fig. 8C). These findings confirmed that HfOx@ZSM-5-(260) possesses a more robust catalytic capacity than pure HfO2, despite its relatively weaker adsorption capacity for FAL. Since the HfOx@ZSM-5-(260) was not enhanced in the initial step of the adsorption reaction but still has a great catalytic activity, we employed them in situ FTIR to investigate the situation of FAL hydrogenation. By simulating the reaction conditions in an in situ pool, the changes in functional groups on the catalyst surface was monitored (excluding itself characteristic peak) every five minutes. As FAL hydrogenation must occur exclusively on the catalyst surface, alterations in functional groups can confirm different hydrogenation pathways on various catalyst surfaces. Fig. 8D illustrates the test results for HfO2. The first peak at 1705 cm−1 was corresponds to C=O bond of FAL, and the new peak appeared at 1657 cm−1 with time extension was also corresponds to this unsaturated aldehyde group of FAL, just because the hydrogenation altered the chemical environment surrounding FAL, thus causing a blue shift [48]. Therefore, this peak at 1657 cm−1 can be considered a feature that initiates the FAL reaction. In the HfOx@ZSM-5-(260) test (Fig. 8E), the initial adsorption capacity of FAL is comparatively weaker than HfO2, which consistent with the adsorption experiments. However, the physical adsorption peak at 1705 cm−1 disappears soon upon reaction initiation (5 min), and the signal to start hydrogenation (characteristic peak at 1657 cm−1) emerged rapidly, indicating prompt onset of FAL hydrogenation upon contact with the catalyst. These findings confirmed that Si doping accelerates the rate-limiting second step involving FAL hydrogenation on the catalyst surface, thereby serving as a crucial factor in promoting catalyst activity. In classical reaction theory, the transfer of hydrogen protons is the main process involved in the second step when both substrate and hydrogen donor are adsorbed on the catalyst [12,49]. Si doping induces a fluffy structure with rich pores and exposes more acidic sites in HfOx@ZSM-5-(260). It also deprives Hf of electrons, resulting in stronger Lewis acidity for proton transfer and even subsequent removal of FOL. This is the reason why it does not have Lewis acidity but still can promote the hydrogenation of FAL (Fig. 9 ). 4 Conclusions In summary, we demonstrate that the architectural integration of ZSM-5 molecular sieves with HfOx enables the design of high-performance catalysts for sustainable CTH of toxic FAL to value-added FOL. The optimized HfOx@ZSM-5-(260) achieved >99 % FAL conversion and FOL yield within 1 h at 160°C, outperforming conventional metal oxides while eliminating the need for high-pressure H2 or energy-intensive conditions. Beyond traditional carrier roles, in situ dissolved silicon species from ZSM-5 orchestrate synergistic structural and electronic effects: partial inhibition of HfOx over-condensation creates hierarchical porosity, exposing more accessible Lewis acid sites compared to non-doped HfOx, while Si-O-Hf interfacial bonding induces electron withdrawal from Hf centers, amplifying Lewis acidity critical for MPV hydride transfer. This strategy delivers significant green process advantages, suppression of hazardous byproducts (e.g., humins and resinification derivatives) via enhanced selectivity (>99 % FOL yield) to reduce post-reaction purification burdens, and retaining >95 % FOL selectivity over three consecutive cycles using low-toxicity Hf/Si precursors, thereby aligning with waste-minimization principles of green chemistry. By redefining the role of zeolite integration in oxide catalyst design, this work showcases how atomic-level heteroatom doping during structural evolution reconciles high activity with environmental sustainability, providing a universal framework to advance green chemistry in heterogeneous catalysis through simultaneous energy efficiency optimization and toxic byproduct suppression. coredata.dc:description: The sustainable transformation of biomass-derived platform molecules into value-added chemicals is pivotal for reducing environmental hazards and fossil resource dependence. Herein, we report a silicon-mediated interface engineering strategy to tailor the Lewis acidity of HfOx catalysts, enabling green catalytic transfer hydrogenation (CTH) of toxic furfural (FAL) to safer furfuryl alcohol (FOL). By integrating ZSM-5 molecular sieves with HfOx through a hydrothermal route, in situ dissolved silicon species were found to dynamically regulate HfOx framework condensation. This process generated hierarchical porosity with accessible acidic sites and formed Si-O-Hf interfacial bonds that induced electron-deficient Hf centers. The optimized HfOx@ZSM-5-(260) catalyst achieved >99 % FAL conversion and FOL selectivity within 1 h at 160°C, effectively suppressing hazardous resinification byproducts. Notably, the catalyst, synthesized from low-toxicity Hf and Si precursors, retained >95 % FOL selectivity over three consecutive cycles, demonstrating robust stability in waste-minimized processes. Mechanistic studies revealed a linear correlation between silicon doping levels and Lewis acid strength, establishing a universal descriptor for eco-friendly catalyst design in hydrogen transfer reactions. This work underscores the potential of interfacial electronic modulation in mitigating toxic byproducts during biomass valorization, offering a sustainable pathway aligned with green chemistry principles.
